abstracts.cdata!:
This Performance Assessment Report
            concurs largely with the Implementation Completion Report,
            and Evaluation Summary's ratings of satisfactory
            project outcome, high institutional development impact, as
            well as highly satisfactory Bank performance, and
            satisfactory Borrower performance, though downgrades its
            sustainability to likely from a highly likely rating.
            Lessons drawn from the project experience, suggest that the
            design of railway concessions should aim to avoid
            establishing government-owned patrimony/landlord
            corporations, since such corporations tend to interfere with
            the management of the concession, with no clear gains for
            the government. Therefore, selling rather than leasing the
            equipment to the concessionaire, leads to a cleaner
            concession arrangement, and thus precludes the need for a
            patrimony corporation. The Bank's experience with
            railway concessions contributes to designing, and financing
            of such operations, in particular, in attracting private
            investors to difficult infrastructure sectors. However, it
            is also suggested that renegotiation of infrastructure
            concessions should be avoided, or deferred as possible,
            since it undermines credibility of the concession system
            itself. And, the delicate issue of staff redundancy, should
            be managed with adequate compensation, providing pensions
            under exceptional early retirements, and outsourcing-company
            work to displaced staff.
